Award.AwardTitle: NUE: Integrating Nanotechnology into Undergraduate Engineering Education at the University of Arkansas

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objectives of this Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education (NUE) in Engineering program entitled, "NUE: Integrating Nanotechnology into Undergraduate Engineering Education at the University of Arkansas", under the direction of Dr. Min Zou, are to 1) develop nanotechnology modules for freshman and sophomore classes; 2) develop a new laboratory to develop student skills with nanotechnology tools; 3) create a multidisciplinary nanotechnology certificate program; and 4) increase the number of undergraduate students participating in undergraduate research. The proposed plan creatively and effectively integrates interdisciplinary nanotechnology education into undergraduate engineering curriculum in the College of Engineering (COE) at the University of Arkansas (UA). Members of the project team are from different departments in the COE and the College of Arts and Sciences, forming an interdisciplinary team that gives the students the broadest exposure to nanotechnology.

The impact of this program is in the development and implementation of an increased learning environment in nanotechnology for the next generation of scientists and engineers who will lead discovery at the nanoscale. Almost all UA COE undergraduate students will be exposed to nanotechnology education starting at the freshman level and a significant portion of them will participate in research in nanotechnology. The proposed plan has the potential to serve as a model for other mid-size graduate institutions that wish to impact the education of undergraduate engineering students in areas of emerging technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanotechnology is a rapidly developing interdisciplinary field that holds great promise for new applications in a wide range of industries that have large societal impacts, including consumer goods, electronics, computers, energy, biotechnology, and medicine. One of the barriers to the commercialization of nanotechnology is insufficient education and workforce preparation. The goal of this project is to effectively integrate nanotechnology into the undergraduate engineering curriculum at the University of Arkansas (UA).

The project team has developed and institutionalized a Nanotechnology Laboratory course and an Interdisciplinary Nanotechnology Minor Program into the UA undergraduate curriculum. The team has also effectively introduced nanotechnology knowledge to the Freshman Engineering Program (FEP) students and integrated nanotechnology research into FEP Annual Honors Research Symposium, research experience for undergraduates (REU), and honors thesis research.

The Nanotechnology Laboratory course has been co-developed by a team of seven faculty members from the College of Engineering (COE) and J. William Fulbright College of Arts and Sciences (CAS) along with their postdoc/graduate/undergraduate students. Each of the seven faculty members has developed one lab module for the course. Together, they have involved 13 postdoc/graduate/undergraduate students in the course development and offering since the project initiation. Through their involvement in the project, the postdoc/students gained solid experimental skills related to their lab modules. They also learned how to develop and teach educational laboratory modules. The Nanotechnology Laboratory course has been institutionalized by cross-listing the course in five departments (Mechanical Engineering, Biomedical Engineering, Biological Engineering, Chemistry, and Physics) in the UA Undergraduate Catalog of Studies and has been offered every Fall semester since Fall 2013 with more than 30 students taken/taking the course.

The Interdisciplinary Nanotechnology Minor Program has been established through the support from both NSF and the University of Arkansas Honors College, which expended the impact of this project to cover both COE and CAS undergraduate students. This minor has been approved by the participating departments, colleges, university, and the Arkansas Department of Higher Education and has been officially included in the Undergraduate Catalog of Studies. The Nanotechnology Minor has been offered since Fall 2013 and 7 students already received the minor with an increasing student demand.

The project team has also developed nanotechnology presentations and delivered many nanotechnology seminars to undergraduate students at various venues such as at the FEP Colloquium, which is attended by more than 120 honors students from the FEP annually. In addition, the project team has provided opportunities for undergraduate students, including students from underrepresented groups, to perform scientific research in nanotechnology. The team has supervised honors freshmen research for the Annual Honors Research Symposium, REU students in their research projects, and seniors in their honors thesis research. The undergraduate students participated in the nanotechnology research acquired skills of literature search, analyzing and presenting experimental data and writing technical reports or papers, which will improve their access to research careers.
